that said, its not clear that Luigi is any kind of lefty. he just seems like a typical right-ish guy who was personally affected by something and took the matter into his own hands. assuming it was him, of course. but he seems like a nice guy apparenlty so there's that at least. idk. its a tough one

author: @OriginalPrimarySource
text: Shirley Chisolm was graceful... but also DIRECT. We can do both. When they gave "it" to Ms. Chisolm, she gave back twice what she got... and never took it to the gutter. Black folks, we gotta change our ways and do the same. It's called Kick-Ass-grace

author: @VanAlexi
text: People protesting Cop City here in Atlanta have been charged with terrorism and been shot dead. Those are people protesting the establishment, yet we hear no justice for them. Miss me with this love for Luigi.

author: @the_deep_velvet
text:
I‚Äôm just really tired of hearing grandstanding about ‚Äúclass solidarity‚Äù from people who aren‚Äôt militant about being in solidarity with the Black people they share class status with.

Like we don‚Äôt share class with Luigi, he‚Äôs not in class solidarity with us. Like the most you could give him is class betrayal, but that can‚Äôt be true of a rich guy that‚Äôs pro-establishment, pro-feds, pro-cop, and just acting on behalf of his singular grievance (if we‚Äôre to believe the story about his back).  

Class can‚Äôt be addressed without race, because the two reify each other. The makeup of class is informed by the constructs of race, and if you want to be ‚Äúin solidarity‚Äù that means caring about the most vulnerable of people that you share class status with, and that will always be Black people, regardless of the other nuances of our experiences.

author: @74JGrant
text:
RE: "Luigi solidarity" There will never be a shift in anything until the people truly realize we have the power, there's too many people deeply fearful of the powers that be. Scared witless about losing their jobs if they stayed home in protest, fear of jail or more if we stopped paying whatever in protest (taxes or fines or rents) it kills me too, the realization that they cannot punish us all just hasn't gotten thru. If 250 million people stopped participating in this mess, it'd flip but it won't happen because of the centuries of fear from "Them".  We need an under the radar org to "turn out the lights" one day on the economy to send the message (stay home/don't buy etc) 
RE: Free speech: yeah...Americans are completely ignorant about what ANY of the Amendments mean. We're 38th in literacy so comprehension is low on what meanings and definitions even are. It has limits and it has consequences. 
RE: Real power: I think humans are kind of "two thought classes" - those who want power for the sake of it and those who want change but "power" is tricky to them because if we see power as its shown forever, this "evil" thing, decent people cringe from it because we don't want what that generally means. Power means control and no one with compassion seeks control they just want things to be equitable for all, ending greed as it is, that kind of thing, so it's tricky for good folks to seek power really, catch 22 - have to have control to make change but control is generally not viewed as a positive thing in regard to government.

author: @spooty5383
text: Thank you Olay for christining the new year with a new Olay and friends.

author: @CheeseLoversUnited
text:
what people are spotting are chances to start to build solidarity. I agree that people tend to be over optimistic when it comes to considering new allies. But allies aren't friends, or people that see eye to eye on everything. They're people that have a common cause for solidarity around hopefully a few things, but sometimes only one cause

that is a fraught and potentially precarious situation but it doesn't mean that it has to be that way or stay that way. 

building solidarity takes work, and it's not work for everyone. But I dont know that people saying this is a marker for increased class consciousness haven't considered that's there's a lot that still actively divided us and works against us when we attempt solidarity

author: @vila777_
text:
hampton‚Äôs rainbow coalition should be the model. we need to bring others together, regardless of race. right now, mentioning privilege to white people leads them to shirk from their responsibilities and avoid the topic of race because deep down they feel ashamed of the idea that they have privilege, or angry because they think white privilege means that they have never struggled before. 

i think we should reframe white privilege and privilege in general as a moral obligation to help others rather than something they need to sit there and feel guilty about. that guilt is not productive right now. rich folk as well need to understand that they are not condemned to hell, they just have a moral imperative to redistribute those resources. a privileged harvard kid like marshall ganz had no problem putting his ego aside and helping cesar chavez and the ufw with his resources. that‚Äôs important. we need more folks in the movement who acknowledge privilege and see it as moral imperative rather than a reason to not join.

replies.author: @IaMSpeaks
replies.text: No one told them to feel guilty. It's not our jobs to bear the brunt of their oppression and to coddle them. Are you hearing yourself right now?

replies.author: @segara04
replies.text: @IaMSpeaks ¬† just to add to what you are saying here, it is like the OP still wants to put responsibility on us for educating them. You are very much right. It feels like coddling. No one told them to feel guilty. We asked them to educate themselves and understand what whiteness is, and they get defensive about it. That is not on us. But again, why are we always asked to handle things with grace and patience while usually getting hit the hardest? (not actually a question for you)

author: @artosbear
text:
I think a lot of people have absolutely zero idea how to do community even when they really give a damn.  My friends and I have been trying to organize people into doing more than friendships: show up and do chores for people.  Do tasks and take the daily load of living off of people so their hearts can grow and the amount of inertia we meet all the time us sooooo huge.  Im finding over and
 over people just dont even KNOW at ALL.  Theyre angry, and theyll go out and do protests if they happen or maybe they do stuff like getting food into peoples mouths and thats important.  But i keep meeting people with zero foundation for just
 daily collectively living.  They go right back into individualism if i mention going to help out a local housing justice org to fix some apartment doors or something. These are people under threat, they have gone through bad stuff, and they have this reflexive reaction still where the basic assumptions dont change.  I mean its happening slowly, i realized just... People dont take care of eschother so we have to regrow it so we are trying to do it.  Its just so effing sloooowwwww.  These are more left inclined people not "liberals." Not even wasting my time less than that and its teaching babies basically.  

Luigi is basically that movie Falling Down.

replies.author: @artosbear
replies.text: The point i was autistically trying to get to was in my experience trying to get people to move collectively is they cant even handle the most basic mutual aid of just handling eachothers daily activities of living on a regular basis.  The individualist conditioning is so deep its just a void for lots of people, and I struggle to see how class solidarity can ever arise and STAY without that foundation.  Idk.

author: @rosethrawn

author: @tormentorox1
text:
The semantics of what it is and isn‚Äôt true ‚Äúclass solidarity‚Äù doesn‚Äôt really matter imo because we‚Äôve never had it and probably never will as long as race as a construct exists. 

What matters is whether or not the coalition is useful. There were tons of people that were slave abolitionist for very different reasons. For example a lot of abolitionist wanted slaves sent back to Africa and didn‚Äôt necessarily want black people living next to them. What matters at the end of the day is that Chattel slavery was ended with that coalition. 

If you can get your average racist Gen X Karen and Dave to agree with you on the solution I don‚Äôt think the rest matters all too much. 

Whether or not they agree on universal healthcare as the solution is the only question for me. If their solution is anti-immigration, racism, and giving billionaires more power then it‚Äôs a useless coalition.

author: @emily3282
text: I was watching citizen4 with Edward Snowden, and he speaks about how we was worried about and wanted to avoid as much as possible the media making the story about him, and who he is as a person, as a distraction from larger issues of mass surveillance, privacy, and human rights. I think Luigi is a fascinating from a sociological standpoint, in part because of his whiteness, affluence, and gender, but the narrative is out of his hands and  those who own the media want us to focus on Luigi the person. With this in mind, we need to stay focused on what matters #M4A

author: @ablackgirlscommentary43
text: THis is honestly so helpful as a college student who is currently interning for an organization at a major university. I do have a question though. How do you deal with organizing for an organization that works hand in hand with the oppression of certain peoples? I don't want to put too many details out there but I am interning for the institute for human development and social change for a major university in New York City, and I am having internal troubles just trying to make peace with the fact that I am completing social work for immigrants but also working under a university that supports fascist regimes.

author: @KwesiTheHermit
text: I have heard so many commenters say ‚Äúa murder was committed,‚Äù and that is incorrect. MURDERS, plural, were committed- and the first, and by far the most, were committed by United Health Care. Violence begets violence, and to condemn the victims of state violence for their retaliatory acts before we condemn the state itself is problematic. I am not saying violence is the answer, but you can only oppress and exploit for so long before it becomes inevitable.

author: @KwesiTheHermit
text: Luigi is not the great white savior, and nothing much will probably change, and yes the reactionary mobilization of the police state is a real possibility. However, you cannot expect a nation of millions of oppressed people to stay totally and completely nonviolent forever, and you cannot expect the state to not fight back, so the only real way to avoid such a tragic and fruitless escalation of death is to show, through action, that other paths to liberation are possible. But Luigi will not be the last, because the state will continue to inflict suffering and the people are not part of a disciplined movement.

author: @elleanna5869
text:
Popular reaction to Luigi's alleged actions could be the start of class consciousness, solidarity and real fight to real injustice.
Sort of miracle in the only country with 2 right wing parties who make their best to avoid "class" even as a word since always ,  and both owned and funded by the same lobbies that fear class solidarity more than everything.

Dismissing people reacting on internet is wrong, even memeing and fangirling -this is the stuff of icons , people were hyping Saint Just for being hot and his earrings were in trend like a Luigi's hoodie .
Thinking that the iconic lore and Jesse James / Joker/ The Adjuster tale can be enough is wrong too, but wasting the chance will be mainly on "smart people above tik tok" especially on dem side of the spectrum,choosing inaction , contented with lecturing pop culture , the rephblicans, the internet, Luigi's persona and all the excuses. Like the Cnn bigots.

There's a lot of work to do now that some good debates are finally open - but it's hard work and it's on people not on icons.

author: @daetsmlowolfuar2056
text: I do have a fairly broad definition of free speech, but I believe that how one exercises their free speech should be admissible to build a case against them. Though I'm also aware, unlike most people seem to be, that the Constitutional free speech only applies to the government as far as being restricted from shutting down voices. Though if any speech should be restricted it should be the hatemongering and racist speech that the "free speechers" are trying to protect.

author: @nikkis8102
text:
While I respect @Msolurin's perspective, I completely disagree with her. I am at 37 mins and I plan on finishing this. She is saying that Lui shooting in New York is going to give them a reason to increase the police state that is there and I feel that is false. New York already has a ridiculous police state and they were going to increase the police state regardless. I mean you are talking about a place where police popped random people due to a single person not paying for their ticket to the metro (idk what it is called). If they try to blame Lui then the effect came before the cause - meaning they had a plan to do something but they found a reason to blame it on afterwards.

Also, saying that Lui can cause people to shoot at immigrants because of some promotion of yt men violence is also false, imo. Again, those people were bound to do that anyways regardless of what Lui did. What Lui did was show other yt men, who are frustrated with the system, who they should be pointing the pew-pew at if they want to point it. There have been several yt men copycats so far who have aimed the pew-pew at yt CEOs. 

Also, the whole point of 'if it was a blk person they wouldn't give him the time to explain himself'. As a black woman, I agree that's true. Every community needs allies. We need yt men to continue to use their yt male privilege to protect everyone else while we work towards more equity. 

This has been said to be the season where blk people are resting, rightfully so. We can support others who are fighting for causes that will benefit our blk community while we rest. Blk people are treated the worst by the healthcare system so we have the most to gain by it changing.

replies.text: @ Maybe, like i feel like there is an actual place of dissatisfaction with insurance, so some support is coming from that. But as far as online discourse I see a lot of people focus more on how attractive he is and it reminded me of how people fawned over Dahmer, overshadowing any real discussion. That‚Äôs what I was trying to get across. It could still be dumb though but that is what it reminded me of.

replies.author: @elleanna5869
replies.text:
He looks ethnic , he is boy next door with some level of charme that goes beyond abs and  conventional model static stuff. Tbh mugshots look sort of troubled real magnetic character, not perfect and then authentic - that dude that later married a heiress was fine but predictable , boring stuff. Not a character, no fascination, Just a luxury item/object (bought by a rich woman)
Not the kind of dude creating havoc and getting  a Gotham perp walk with a mayor behind

Luigi as an icon/ book/novels /fiction/ movie material is objectively huge. As a political figure - uhm. Not really  He's the alleged firestarter in every alleged way of the most basic and long overdue social conversation, but people should move on from his persona and stand up for their rights.
